Award.AwardTitle: Petascale Integrative Approaches to Protein Structure Prediction

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project addresses a central challenge of biology: the prediction of protein structure from sequence. Accurate determination of protein structure is essential to understanding biological mechanism and designing new drugs. The purpose of this work is to use the petascale capabilities of Blue Waters to overcome limitations of current experimental and computational tools of structure determination. The project will do this by running a physics-based simulation method, called MELD (Modeling Employing Limited Data) that rationally incorporates sparse, noisy, and ambiguous experimental or heuristic information. Currently around 15% of protein targets cannot be tackled by known methods. The transformative goal of this work is to use MELD, running on Blue Waters, to break substantial barriers in size and complexity for computational structure prediction.

This work has three major goals: (1) use MELD to provide structures for the known, small proteins were bioinformatics methods fail and where databases are sparse (e.g. membrane proteins), (2) provide kinetic and pathway information for protein folding by seeding Markov State Models (MSM) with MELD intermediate states, and (3) use accurate relative free energies of folding upon binding for more accurate peptide design. The project will use the the petascale capabilities of Blue Waters to push the size boundaries of full atomistic physics based predictions. Both the software and the results obtained from this project will be freely accessible to the larger scientific community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We used the petascale computational resources of Blue Waters to break substantial barriers in size and complexity for computational prediction of protein structures, protein motion, and drug binding. We did this by running a physics-based simulation method, called MELD (Modeling Employing Limited Data). MELD is based on a Bayesian inference framework to accelerate simulations based on sparse, noisy, and ambiguous data sources. These kinds of information are relatively easy to come across from experiments or theory, but they are usually challenging to incorporate into computational methods due to their “fuzzy” nature.  MELD pulls into a single simulation several of this data in order limits the search space of the problem at hand. The physics-based engine is then able to quickly pick out the right answer from this reduced search space.

We used MELD to tackle several challenging problems of structural biology:

(1) Knowing the 3D structure of a protein is key in structural biology. Most computational methods in structure prediction are based on homology, that means that they can quickly predict the structure of proteins that are similar to the proteins we already know but are quite lost when no similar structures are available. By combining general knowledge of protein with accurate physics model, we correctly identified the structure of a series of proteins that were impossible to predict using homology methods.

(2) In the international protein structure prediction competition called CASP we were the top group in predicting protein structure with the help of NMR experimental data. This data is a prime example of sparse and ambiguous data. An expert typically requires months to disambiguate all the NMR data manually and produce an accurate 3D structure. MELD uses this data to drive the exploration of the physics-based simulation, that can quickly (days of simulation) and reliably identify the correct structure.

(3) MELD can add significant value as last step of a pipeline to predict how protein binds to each other. Most methods, in order to curb computational cost, do not account for protein flexibility. MELD is not bound by this limitation. We showed that feeding into MELD information from rigid predictions yield higher quality predictions compared to rigid docking methods.

(4) Using MELD we can compare the binding affinity of different drug molecules to a protein and screen different possible hypothetical binding poses of a drug to a protein. The solution to both of these problems requires the estimation of the difference in free energy of different structures, that is made possible by MELD not affecting the energy of regions of the search space that agree with external data. We used MELD to successfully screen different binding poses for drugs in the D3R international competition.

(5) The physics engine at the core of MELD allows us to study the kinetic of proteins and protein folding. We showed how MELD simulations can quickly provide valuable starting points for methods that describe protein folding routes and kinetic.
